issues.description: Whether the district court erred in denying a preliminary injunction against enforcement of Nantucket's car rental ordinance on dormant Commerce Clause grounds.
issues.key_reasoning: The district court did not clearly err in finding insufficient evidence that the ordinance had a discriminatory effect on interstate commerce, as it favored incumbents regardless of in-state or out-of-state status and no out-of-state enterprise was shown to be burdened.

issues.description: Whether the ordinance violates federal and state antitrust law by unreasonably restraining trade.
issues.key_reasoning: Plaintiffs failed to articulate a concrete antitrust theory or likelihood of success on the merits, so the district court did not abuse its discretion in denying relief.

issues.description: Whether the ordinance violates procedural due process by depriving plaintiffs of a property interest in a license.
issues.key_reasoning: Even if plaintiffs had a property interest in a license, they failed to show a property interest in medallions, which are also required to operate, so no likelihood of success was shown.

issues.description: Whether the ordinance violates substantive due process.
issues.key_reasoning: The ordinance is rationally related to legitimate government interests in traffic and congestion, and thus survives rational basis review.

key_precedents: Russomano v. Novo Nordisk Inc., 960 F.3d 48 (1st Cir. 2020)
New Energy Co. of Ind. v. Limbach, 486 U.S. 269 (1988)
Wine & Spirits Retailers, Inc. v. Rhode Island, 481 F.3d 1 (1st Cir. 2007)
FCC v. Beach Commc'ns, Inc., 508 U.S. 307 (1993)
Naser Jewelers, Inc. v. City of Concord, 513 F.3d 27 (1st Cir. 2008)
summary_text: In 2023, James Broad and Rebecca McCrensky began operating a car-rental agency, Becky's Broncos, LLC (collectively with Broad and McCrensky, "Becky's"), without the requisite approval from local authorities -- the Town of Nantucket and Nantucket Town Select Board (collectively, "Nantucket"). Nantucket soon ordered Becky's to stop its unsanctioned car-rental operations, prompting Becky's to seek preliminary injunctive relief in the District of Massachusetts. For the following reasons, we affirm the district court's denial of Becky's request.
